name: Buehler, John
cj: He is listed as a maltster in 1869. In 1871 he is listed as alderman and bank agent. It is likely he is both the John Buehler who became an Illinois state senator and the wealthy banker whose will was filed in 1899. However, the name is common and the banker also had a son and nephew named John who were involved in the bank. (Tribune)

name: Gage, David A.
cj:
Brother of George W.
  • After losing the election for Treasurer in 1873, there was a reported shortage of $507,000 in city funds. Public funds were invested very differently back then, so the case makes little sense in modern terms. Gage was criminally charged, but acquitted. He and his backers were held civilly liable and required to repay the money. Legal cases dragged on until 1934. (Tribune)
  • Death: April 11, 1889, New Hampshire

name: Harrison , Carter (1825-1893)
cj:
Note on names: The elder Mayor Carter Henry Harrison was the third of that name, his son the fourth. Both mayors and their contemporaries confusingly referred to both mayors as Carter Harrison. Possibly the elder Harrison tended to use Carter H. Harrison and the younger Carter Henry Harrison. The younger mayor's son (number five) was referred to as Carter Henry Harrison. Jr. As Junior had no sons, there was no sixth.
  • Memorial: Journal of the City Council November 16, 1893 p.1123

name: Hildreth, James H.
cj:
Indicted February 11, 1876 for a scheme to avoid paying tax on 200,000 gallons of whiskey, plead guilty, then fled to Canada. He returned to Chicago, ran for and won an aldermanic race in 1877. The Council refused to seat him. After winning the 1880 election, he was seated over protests. (Tribune) He received a presidential pardon (Hildreth v. Heath)
  • Death: March 22, 1908
  • Memorial: Journal of the City Council March 23, 1908 p.4597
